stormpot
Interface Pool<T extends Poolable>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of Poolable contained in the pool, as determined by the configured allocator.
All Known Subinterfaces:
LifecycledPool<T>
All Known Implementing Classes:
QueuePool
public interface Pool<T extends Poolable>

A Pool is a self-renewable set of objects from which one can claim exclusive access to elements, until they are released back into the pool.

Pools contain Poolable objects. When you claim an object in a pool, you also take upon yourself the responsibility of eventually releasing that object again. By far the most common idiom to achieve this is with a try-finally clause: 

 SomePoolable obj = pool.claim();
 try {
   // do useful things with 'obj'
 } finally {
   obj.release();
 }

Promises

A pool makes a certain number of promises about its implementation and behaviour:
  • A pool will contain at least one object, provided it is able to allocate one. In other words, a pool cannot be constructed with a size less than 1.
  • A pool will ensure that it at no point in time has more allocated objects than what its size permits. As an effect of this, a pool of size 1 that contains an expired object, will deallocate this one object before allocating its replacement.
  • A pool will use the Allocator provided in its configuration for allocating and deallocating objects.
  • A call to claim() on a depleted pool will wait until an object is released by another thread and claimed by the current thread, or the current thread is interrupted.
  • A call to claim(long, TimeUnit) will return an object if one can be secured within the specified timeout period, or null if the timeout elapses, or the current thread is interrupted.
  • A call to claim(long, TimeUnit) will return within the time-out period (to a reasonable degree) even if calls to the allocators allocate method blocks forever.
  • A call to claim(long, TimeUnit) will not wait if the timeout value is less than one. And if a null is passed for the TimeUnit, then an IllegalArgumentException is thrown.
  • If the current thread is interrupted upon entry to claim() or claim(long, TimeUnit) then an InterruptedException will be thrown immediately.
  • If a thread is waiting in a call to one of the claim methods, and the thread gets interrupted, then it will wake up and throw an InterruptedException.
  • If a call to one of the claim methods throws an InterruptedException, then the threads interrupted flag will be cleared, and Thread.interrupted() will return false.
  • A pool will reuse allocated objects within a period specified by the configured time-to-live.
  • A pool will replace expired objects - objects that have, or are about to, outlive the time-to-live - with new ones, to the best of its effort.
  • A pool will not deallocate an object more than once. Not even if it is expired, and released more than once by mistake.
  • A pool will let exceptions thrown by the Allocators allocate method propagate through claim, wrapped in a PoolException.
  • A pool will maintain its invariants, and remain usable, after the Allocators' allocate method has thrown an exception. And should the Allocator stop throwing exceptions from allocate(), then the pool will return to functioning normally.
  • A pool will silently swallow exceptions thrown by the Allocators deallocate method. Those who are interested in the exceptions thrown by this method, must wrap their Allocators in error-checking code.
Pools that are also lifecycled make an additional number of promises:
  • A pool that has been shut down will prevent claims by throwing an IllegalStateException.
  • Threads that are waiting in claim() or claim(long, TimeUnit) for an object to become available, will wake up and receive an IllegalStateException when the pool is shut down.
  • A pool will deallocate all of its objects, before the shut down procedure completes.
  • The shut down procedure of a pool will not deallocate anything other than objects that has been allocated by the Allocator - no nulls or other types of garbage.
  • Calling shutdown on a LifecycledPool will return fast, even if objects are claimed at the time of invocation.
  • Calling shutdown on a LifecycledPool will initiate the shut down procedure even if the calling thread is in the interrupted state. The interruption state of the thread will not be affected by calling this method.
  • Awaiting the completion of the shut down procedure of a pool, will return when all claimed objects are released and subsequently deallocated, and all internal resources of the pool have been freed.
  • Awaiting the completion with a timeout will return false if the wait time elapses before the shut down procedure completes. If it does complete, however, then the method returns true. Awaiting the completion with a timeout, of a shut down procedure that has already finished by the time the await method is called, will immediately return true.
  • An InterruptedException will be thrown if a thread is in the interrupted state when calling an await method on the shut down Completion, or if the thread becomes interrupted while waiting.
  • A pool will silently swallow exceptions thrown the Allocators deallocate method that are thrown during the shut down procedure.

Author:
Chris Vest <mr.chrisvest@gmail.com>

Method Summary
 T claim()
          Claim the exclusive rights until released, to an object in the pool.
 T claim(long timeout, TimeUnit unit)
          Claim the exclusive rights until released, to an object in the pool.
 

Method Detail

claim

T claim()
                         throws PoolException,
                                InterruptedException
Claim the exclusive rights until released, to an object in the pool. Possibly waiting for one to become available if the pool has been depleted.

This method may throw a PoolException if the pool have trouble allocating objects. That is, if its assigned Allocator throws exceptions from its allocate method, or returns null.

An InterruptedException will be thrown if the thread has its interrupted flag set upon entry to this method, or is interrupted while waiting. The interrupted flag on the thread will be cleared after this, as per the general contract of interruptible methods.

Memory effects:

  • The release of an object happens-before any subsequent claim or deallocation of that object, and,
  • The allocation of an object happens-before any claim of that object.

Returns:
An object of the Poolable subtype T to which the exclusive rights have been claimed.
Throws:
PoolException - If an object allocation failed because the Allocator threw an exception from its allocate method, or returned null.
InterruptedException - if the current thread is interrupted upon entry, or becomes interrupted while waiting.

claim

T claim(long timeout,
        TimeUnit unit)
                         throws PoolException,
                                InterruptedException
Claim the exclusive rights until released, to an object in the pool. Possibly waiting up to the specified amount of time for one to become available if the pool has been depleted.

This method may throw a PoolException if the pool have trouble allocating objects. That is, if its assigned Allocator throws exceptions from its allocate method, or returns null.

An InterruptedException will be thrown if the thread has its interrupted flag set upon entry to this method, or is interrupted while waiting. The interrupted flag on the thread will be cleared after this, as per the general contract of interruptible methods.

Memory effects:

  • The release of an object happens-before any subsequent claim or deallocation of that object, and,
  • The allocation of an object happens-before any claim of that object.

Parameters:
timeout - The value of the maximum permitted time-slice to wait for an object to become available. A value of zero or less means that the call will do no waiting.
unit - The unit of the timeout parameter. Must not be null.
Returns:
An object of the Poolable subtype T to which the exclusive rights have been claimed, or null if the timeout period elapsed before an object became available.
Throws:
PoolException - If an object allocation failed because the Allocator threw an exception from its allocate method, or returned null.
InterruptedException - if the current thread is interrupted upon entry, or becomes interrupted while waiting.
IllegalArgumentException - if the unit argument is null.
